The special effects are awesome, if you like Euro and Brazilian modern... hey, Pete Postlethwaite is there, in a ghostly homage to himself as actor and embodied spirit of the authentic keeper of human offspring. Just dig it. The music is great, and very inventive at times. Great work, Graeme Revell. This is a fine movie to enjoy, extremely well made and directed, and serve it up, if you like double features, with either (OK, my choices) The Tenth Victim, or a decade or two more currently, Lara Croft: Tomb Raider. Or much more currently, the Hunger Games.

review_title: well i left feeling a bit empty to be honest...

review_detailed_main:
Managed to get free tickets for the film premiere in Singapore. Only 30%-40% attendance, not very promising.

My heart sank further when I saw "MTV Film Productions" in the opening credits.

My worst fears were realised when the film went through an extended 1-hour long MTV sequence of plodding contrived dialogue delivered in a monotone, meaningless action sequences, and "creative" camera shots.

It was only until the last 15 minutes of the show that we realise what the show was all about. Even so, the climax got a "ok... so that's it?" reaction from the audience.

The basic premise is actually quite good and provides lots of room for exploration. Unfortunately, this film never got around to it. Somehow, the director contrived to make an action film feel agonisingly slow-paced.

This show just scrapes a passing 5 stars, thanks to Charlize Theron's fantastic figure.
I watched the animated series and enjoyed it. I also enjoyed this version. Beautiful sets, colorful story and Charlize Theron. Don't be fooled by the fool critics.

review_title: At least it's not as bad as Catwoman. Yippee.
review_detailed_main:
"I hope the movie's better than the animated MTV series," my cousin scoffed as the opening credits played. Since I had never seen the Aeon Flux short films (and I dare not judge them) I inquired, "Was it not very good?" "No," my cousin informed me.

The fact that my cousin was asleep within 10 minutes tipped me off that he was as unimpressed with the movie as he was the original series. I shouldn't be too surprised. It's usually not a positive sign when a movie's only nationwide screenings are 10:00 PM the night before its release and press aren't officially invited. I suppose it's a good strategy in one sense - lull people to sleep at this late hour and then they can't, in good conscience, ridicule what they weren't awake to see.

Holding out hope that the movie would at least be mindless entertainment, I assumed the studio knew the critics had their pun guns loaded and were ready to fire off such headlines as ... wait for it ...

"Aeon Flux? More like Aeon Sux!"

Therefore, I gave Paramount the benefit of the doubt. "Ah, this is just a case of the studio saying they don't care what the critics think," I said to myself, trying to remain positive. "They're only concerned with how much the movie will entertain regular moviegoers. This is a movie for the people, not the stuffed-shirt critics!" How naive I was.

Now I'm not demanding the second coming of Star Wars whenever a new sci-fi film is released, but does it hurt to do *something* to stand out from the pack? Earning the title of "2005's Most Generic Sci-Fi" does not count. Uninspired acting, a lack of an imaginative story, no strong villain to root against, weakly-rendered CGI, and a pace that my dead pet turtle could keep up with aren't my ideal ingredients for a fun night at the theater. Sure, Charlize looks really good sashaying in her black outfit, but look where Halle Berry's ability to look smokin' hot in black leather got Catwoman.

Speaking of the unimaginative story, I'm starting to feel a little guilty.

"About what? Being so hard on Aeon Flux?"

No, about my detailed plot description. Allow me to apologize. Reading my synopsis, you may be misled to believe that the story is fairly intriguing. Admittedly, on paper the story looks to have promise, but the paper is where the promise stays.

For example, you remember those secrets that my synopsis said Aeon would uncover? Sounds interesting, right? Ooooh, deadly secrets will be revealed! Bring on the tense plot twists! If only. The most novice of sci-fi fans will have the basics figured out within the first 10 minutes. Let me put it bluntly: Aeon wants to kill Trevor Goodchild, she figures out that something's fishy, Trevor has a brother (Miller), and we immediately see them at odds. Care to guess how this will pan out?

"Well, at least there was a lot of cool, fast-paced action and mesmerizing special effects, right?"

I wish. That's what shocks me most. I figured, "OK, I'll go ahead and assume I won't get much in regard to story and character development. But at least the effects should impress." If you've seen the trailer where Charlize barely stops herself from falling in the blades of grass then you've seen about the best the movie has to offer in the effects department. That's not high praise. Everything else consists of Aeon showing off her mad acrobatic skills. Whenever you see her jump you can take it to the bank that a flip will be incorporated, and you can guarantee that the flip will serve no useful purpose.

The gunfights are of the "Charlize stands in one spot, turns around, shoots a bunch of guys, but doesn't get hurt" variety, while the hand-to-hand combat is an extra mild "show extreme close-ups so people can't tell that Charlize doesn't know how to fight" flavor. But the action sequences are only inserted whenever the director decides it's a good idea to break away from long "Charlize slowly walking around looking at stuff" sequences.

And if the slow pace isn't enough to make you regret shelling out hard-earned dollars for this ticket, then I have a feeling the trite dialogue will force you to analyze future movie choices more carefully. We're treated to such deliciously uninspired lines as "I'd keep off the grass," "I like my shoes," and "I've been your brother for a long time." The actors deliver these lines with such a void of emotion that it's obvious they know the lines aren't worthy of even a little mock passion.

I'm all for superhero films with a strong female lead, mainly because I love watching hot chicks wearing cool outfits and kicking Kirstie Alley-sized buttocks. In my opinion, Kate Beckinsale in Underworld has set the modern day standard. So I was actually looking forward to Aeon Flux (surely you can't go wrong with Charlize Theron, right?). Unfortunately, its mediocrity falls somewhere between the levels set by Catwoman and Elektra, and it'll simply be known as another action/superhero movie that couldn't be saved merely because it boasts a sexy lead.

As for my napping cousin? When he awoke and noticed the closing credits were scrolling he asked (and you may wonder the same thing if you decide to skip it), "What did I miss?" The most passionate answer I could come up with was, "Not much."

This movie is billed as sci-fi, which is sort of true, but it really seems more like a fleshed-out dream -- like the writer had a dream he really liked and he built a whole story to go around it and show off all the weird things that happened in it. This aspect, while it may seem incidental, makes the film what it is. Without this, the movie would be trash.

That said, the rest of the film isn't *completely* without merit: Charlize Theron does take her clothes off.

Seriously, though, the film isn't groundbreaking, but it's gripping enough to carry us along for it's ride. What we come out with is a decent popcorn flick -- eye candy -- but not much more than that. Watch this film for the environments and artistry, but don't go in expecting anything more.

My local cinema has 'unlimited' cards. For a set fee per month, you can see as many films as you like. Thats why I saw this film, It was free. And so I don't feel cheated. It's not, by any means, the worst film I've ever seen. Not by quite some way. However, it is not a good film.

As the title indicates, I have issues with this Hollywood trend of hiring good looking people, passing over talented people. Charlize Theron, at least, isn't a Ham actress; there are hardly any clumsily performed scenes. She avoids this by not trying to act.

What little plot there is, is predicated on a post-apocalyptic society. Obviously this lends itself towards social comment. This is, at best blunt. And at worst, see-through. There are no really viable comments made. Having said that, the story-line is moderately complex. There is a reason for this: The film takes on twists, Special Effects, Violence, Futuristic Gadgets and Eye Candy to disguise, make that attempt to disguise, the vacuity at its core.

I wouldn't see it again, even for free. Its not repulsive, its just not particularly enjoyable.

review_title: Action yes, but interesting issues too?
review_detailed_main: While lots of action takes place in Aeon Flux, and there are lots of interesting things to look at, including the city and the people, what captures me about this film are the broader questions it raises. Was the decision to build Bregna and maintain its population, while withholding critical information, ethical or scientifically justified? Was the power play between the Goodchild brothers inevitable? Was the leadership of the Goodchilds (to which the Monicans are rebelling) responsive to the needs of the people? Would a population ever accept the societal structure of Bregna? To me, Aeon Flux simply raises too many interesting questions about how humanity deals with crises and the roles of leaders and rebellions to dismiss as just a B Sci-Fi movie. Something about the film continues to capture my interest, even after watching all the Peter Chung animated shorts, which really seem only loosely related.

review_title: Things are only what they seem
review_detailed_main:
The audience for this movie should be divided in two.

Those who don't know the original series - they should not see the movie for it will appear unimaginative, derivative, and pointless; and those who do know the MTV series - they should not see the movie for the same reasons. Society of clones apparently imagined by a clone, it is a singular story lacking any serious duplicity - a unilateral construction of a futuristic knowledge/power apparatus petrified in its own monumentality.

Single moment of grace: splendid architectural shots.

Worse deviation: Aeon does not move along the vibration charts of insectile swarms, Trevor does know what he wants, and things are crystal clear as if presented by the director's voice-over.

Imagined/suggested quote: 'Seems like confusion should not always be avoided.'

This is X-Men meets Matrix. Or... this is what the Next Generation movies could have been.

Sor far, this is the best movie I've seen all year - better than Chronicles of Narnia & Harry Potter. In the Sci-Fi world, it's a step up from Minority Report or I-Robot.

My interpretation of the negative reviews: that stuffy old white men who write the reviews (Ebert, etc) don't understand edgy movies. They didn't understand Matrix at first, either.

I didn't know there was a series before I saw the movie. People who say it didn't make sense at first are too used to brainless Hollywood flicks, serving you a formulaic plot on a platter.

This plot was not difficult to understand - the movie asks for your patience the first 30 minutes, as the story unfolds. It's a futuristic mystery, people! Get real - how lazy must you be if you lose interest because everything isn't explained immediately. It's a mildly (and pleasantly) complex story. If you want a Steven Siegal or Schwarzenegger action flick, look elsewhere.

And only the first half of the movie is the "mystery". It takes about an hour for the plot, the characters, and the futuristic setting to unfold. Then the movie evolves into a stunning action flick.

Thing I loved about this movie:

-Srong female characters -Excellent soundtrack -Extremely interesting visually -Extremely creative sci-fi contributions (like the arm-to-leg transplants) -Thoughtful cinematography -A very strong cast -Artistic sets & effects -Creative weapons & futuristic props -A truly unique story - it didn't try to copy anything (which probably confused the Hollywood lemmings out there)

My only complaint - it needed more in spots. Particularly, more character development for other members of the resistance. If you've seen it...I believe they jumped the gun getting to the last "sniper" scene. I wanted them to invest more time developing the animosity between Aeon Flux & the resistance movement.

Nonetheless, I'm hoping for a sequel. And I hope Ms Theron doesn't get depressed about some of the bad reviews. This is *nothing* like Catwoman (as Ebert said). My humble prediction: it will turn into a cult classic.

It sickens me to think I actually sat through a full forty-five minutes of this dreck (purely to humour my relatives who had turned it on).

Honestly, how could a human with even the slightest modicum of intelligence possibly enjoy this trash? With a script written collectively by a fourth-grade class from a California elementary school as an English assignment ('I've got it: little metal balls that respond to whistling and reduce walls to rubble on command!'), villains played by "actors" who tried their hand at Hollywood only after their Boy-Band careers fizzled, and more utterly preposterous action sequences than the latest Jackie Chan offering (with the obvious difference being of course that Chan's are, what's that word -- oh yes, good), this piece of cinematic refuse is a resounding insult to homo sapiens and everything he has striven to achieve over the course of the past several hundred millennia.

Ogling Charlize Theron's body in that oh so tight outfit is the only thing this rubbish is good for -- although I do hear DVDs can be melted down and recast as interesting Christmas tree ornaments.

review_title: A brilliant storyline and deserves at least a 7.3

review_detailed_main:
I must admit that I am not a big fan of action films or science fiction adaptations to the big screen (as they are so often badly done). Moreover, I was very tired when screening this film.

That said, this film is one of the most boring I have ever seen, and I am an incredibly patient viewer.

All in all, this is typical Hollywood style sci-fi action fare

Lots of action. - No real excitement. - No genuine emotional connection. - Precious little intellectual stimulation. - A waste of otherwise accomplished acting talent. - Great set design though, but this is not Architectural Digest.


Avoid it, even on DVD. The more you feed the Hollywood monster by supporting schlock like this, the worse it will get.

Jason

review_title: I can tell by the way I feel after I walk out...
review_detailed_main:
I had an afternoon to burn, and wanted to see a movie that a.) my wife and daughter didn't want to see, and b.) I DID want to see.

I always liked the animated shorts on MTV's Liquid TV. They were different, not the standard drivel. I checked the reviews and IMDb score and saw this movie wasn't rated well (mid-5). So I was taking a chance.

Besides having an interesting plot or decent acting, I can tell a good movie by the way I feel when I walk out. I had to wander through the mall after this movie, and I was in a good mood. Uplifted. It's hard to describe, but you probably know the feeling. All the women I passed were attractive (whether they were pretty or not) and I noticed all the children ambling around were precious. My appreciation for life and happiness were raised, if only for a few hours.

Other people have commented on the scenery, the backgrounds, and such. How drab the people look and how bland the buildings are, etc. Some have said the hair styles were too weird. I say - whatever. I am not primarily interested in the set. If you want wacky scenery, go rent The Fifth Element or if you want dreary future scenery get Blade Runner - both decent (or better) films. I am interested in the character development and the story. Would this movie have been much better if they spent $30 million on CGI backgrounds or exotic costumes? Not really. Remember the series often had a similar utilitarian look - and that look serves the story as an emotional backdrop in certain ways. So I discount those criticisms.

Now, I admit I don't like a lot of the movies aimed at teenagers. I don't like a lot of gratuitous violence or sex if the story doesn't call for it. This movie didn't overdo it, it was more subtle than that. It generally focuses on what serves the story. Refreshing in that way.

I see the demographics have a lot of votes for 10 (20%) and a lot of votes of 1 (13%). '1' votes are unfair in my opinion. There is no way this is the worst movie ever set to film. Obvious attempts to tank a score. But I understand how maybe some people did not care for the film - it ISN'T standard Hollywood formula junk. No car chases or anything! No over-hyped drawn out sex scenes! Not mindless entertainment! Wait, that's what I liked about it.

This movie deserves to be a high 6. It was much better than the other movies I've seen rated mid-5 here on IMDb. Those generally leave me feeling poorer by $10-20 and not uplifted at all. It may be 'low budget' and it may be 'different' but it is worth seeing on the big screen, especially if you enjoyed the series at all.

Charlize Theron is Beautiful, a talented actress, and an inspired choice for the Mtv heroine Aeon Flux. The costumes were fun ( if impractical) and some of the set designs were absolutely gorgeous.It's a shame that all that's good about this movie.

Aeon flux was a very edgy offensive sexually charged cartoon several years ago. This was Aeon Flux in Disneyland. A rehashed plot about a rebel group fighting a totalitarian government harboring a secret that could cripple the Utopian society. Been there... done that... about a million times, and this film adds nothing new to the formula, except a few more plot holes. A city of maybe 4000 people is recycled for 400 years and no one notices, I guess they were distracted by the couture designs. It's amazing how many varied fabrics you can get in an isolated "last" city on earth.

The action sequences are choppy, some of the special effects are unconvincing, and the fake twists and turns in the plot seem like afterthoughts. They should have went full tilt on Aeon. Made her edgier, more cut-throat, and more interesting. Instead we get "catwoman 2:into the future" There is a scene where some vital liquid technology is flushed down a drain...seems like the film pretty much followed.

review_title: Not as bad as I thought it would be
review_detailed_main:
Once again, expectations greatly color reaction. I was excited about this and wanted to see it when I heard about it but then I heard how awful it was. I delayed and it left the theaters before I saw it. I was not overly upset since I had heard so much negative. Then I was excited about seeing Ultraviolet and it was awful so I figured I had really done good by missing Aeon Flux in the theaters but I remained curious.

It came out on DVD and I made a point to see it the day it came out. My 15 year old daughter watched it with me. The plot was a little odd but we could both follow it. I am a huge Sci-fi fan, she is only passingly interested in it so I figure that must mean that the plot is okay. That is a good word for this movie - okay. The action is okay, not outstanding but not awful. The special effects are okay. The progress of technology is okay. The explanation of the characters and their backstory is okay.

The basics are that in 2011, a virus kills 99% of the population before a Dr. Goodchild discovers a vaccine and is able to save the rest. He creates a walled utopian society and the movie is now 400 years later. There is a group which opposes him called the Monicans (though that name is never explained and that bugged me). That is the most I can say without giving away too much of the plot but the movie does a good job of following its premise (unlike Ultraviolet). It stuck with its story and did not sidetracked so I appreciated that.

This is not a must-see movie but I am glad I saw it. It was pleasant enough and was not a total waste of time and money. Maybe on the big screen of a theater, it came across better or worse but if you are in a sci-fi mood, you could do much worse than this movie.

review_title: If you haven't seen the animated series, it's recommended to see the movie first
review_detailed_main: If you haven't seen any of the animated episodes for Aeon Flux, and think you need to before you watch this movie, don't bother.. Just go and see the movie first or you will feel severely ripped off.. The main thing that disappointed me was how badly they f***ed up the characters.. In the Animated series, while Flux was a "good guy", she was also very narcissistic, vindictive, manipulative, sarcastic and had a way sexier presence than her movie version, over all she was a bitch. (this isn't to say that Charlize Theron didn't play a good part, I blame the script writers for her character f**k up) Also in the series, Trevor Goodchild is a bastard and is manipulative and narcissistic himself but he also has a bit of a soft side,if you have seen the animated series but still want to see the movie go for it, but I wouldn't recommend it if you are a big fan of the series because you will be sorely disappointed.. The 3 stars is because Charlize Theron looked hot, and did her best to play a badly written character

review_title: If you're in for a bit of mind-bending sci-fi, Aeon Flux will certainly do
Not for animated Aeon Flux fans.
review_detailed_main:
Aeon Flux was a decent movie, but not nearly as great as the animated shorts and series. If you are a huge fan of the cartoon, this movie can be very disappointing.

The original relationship of Trevor Goodchild and Aeon Flux is a bit warped, and there isn't the same amount of sexual tension and lust as the cartoons. Also the city Monica seems to be completely left out of the story. Which takes away from the original fight between cities. Only a few characters are originally from the series and shorts.

The storyline is good and consistent, but not nearly as twisted as the cartoon.

It is a good movie, but not a great remake of the original Peter Chung cartoon.

Seriously good costume design, Seriously good looking people, Seriously high number of fight scenes, Seriously high number of rail deaths, Seriously cute actress, Seriously funky looking shoes, Seriously well designed DVD, Seriously asking for Aeon Flux II, Seriously not all that much like the toon, Seriously interesting set design, Seriously Seriously DULL.

Terry

review_title: Mostly style over substance, but I liked it!!

review_detailed_main:
I watched the original comic series this movie is based on and really liked that one. But this was back in the days, I was younger, of course, and so I had mixed feelings when I went to see the adaptation on the big screen. To my surprise the movie wasn't that bad at all. It was far from being great, granted. But it entertains for the most part, which can't be said about many other films, which are broadly praised.

The acting is good, the effects are good and the sets are really good. And they really made Charlize Theron wear some of Aeon Flux' silly outfits.

The major weakness in my opinion is the level of seriousness the movie tries to keep. It just doesn't work. They either should have thrown in a little humor or deviate more from the comic. But being as it is, the movie got a bit slow at times. At least it is not expected for you to know the comic series.

Go and give this movie a try. Honestly, it's not as bad as many people say. If you like SF you will at least be entertained for 90 minutes.

review_title: an hour and a half of my life I'm not getting back
review_detailed_main:
So many things wrong with this movie. Bad acting all around (including Frances McDormand and Jonny Lee Miller), bad writing, bad costume design, weak score, and lame special effects. Five years ago the visuals might have been stunning, but now they're fairly weak. If you're a fan of the original series, this movie falls far short of maintaining the mind-trip experience. If you're a fan of dystopian sci-fi, this is nothing more than a hackneyed attempt at eye candy.

The theater I went to had approx. 300 seats and was roughly 4/5 full. Somewhere around 30 people walked out before the film was over. This should tell you what you need to know.

Don't even waste your time downloading it.

Having recently received an Academy Award for dressing down to play the serial killer Aileen Wournos Charlese Theron made this prime example of Hollywood's taste for glamorising mass slaughter by killing considerably more people in this live action version of the activities of the titular assassin.

Set in a pristine and well-tended future, 'Aeon Flux' certainly looks good, and the chic black bob sported by Charlese Theron definitely suits her. It's too bad she didn't wear the tiny bikini and big boots worn by the original, but even an assassin has her standards and Ms Theron was presumably too coy and too big a star to accede to such immodest attire.

Are you kidding me. This was so bad my I couldn't contain laughing towards the end, and one of my friends (there were 5 of us) had to say something like "quit laughing you @*sshole" but even so he himself soon started laughing and eventually we rolled out feeling better than American Pie or whatever movie it is that forces you to laugh could ever make us.

If you're looking for that "oh i'm so stupid, I just blew $15 on tickets and popcorn FOR THIS" feeling, expect great laughs, because just when it seems that this movie cannot possibly get any worse it DOES.

Recommended to whoever watched LXG (League of Extraordinary Gentlemen) or Catwoman 10 times and cherishes these two in their collection.

~O~

It starts off strong and is pretty true to the animated original. Theron is excellent and I loved the casting- though thrown by the non-blond Chairman at first. Also top marks for an super ethnically diverse cast of all genders which was amazing considering it was made in 2005. Visually everything is quite stunning, decors are fantastic, costumes, gadgets...

Then, about half way in, things take a turn for the worse. It's really too bad. You can really tell where the producers cut the movie to shreds from Kusama's original edit. You're left with a hollow, almost hokey and mind numbingly simplistic plot reveal. The last 20 minutes of the film is a wash, even the final action sequences are terrible: confusing and even worse, boring.

I was left feeling disappointed and wishing for a directors cut.

review_title: The Good, The Bad and the Greatness Missed
review_detailed_main:
It's no worse than 70% of the formulaic rehashes that finance the commercial movie industry in terms of mass entertainment, and it at least tries to be unique and innovative. I didn't feel cheated in the way I was with, for instance, "John Q" (the political advertisement ghost written by Hillary Clinton which I was forced to pay to see and which forever barred me from Denzel's movies on principle).

The story hasn't been told before, the world hasn't been seen, the pacing is consistent, although slower than we expect for an action film (which Aeon Flux the animation was not primarily), and the special effects equal to today's standards. As eye candy, it certainly delivers.

I leave the "bad" items to the many negative reviews already here, which are mostly technical.

However... the worst is that a chance to establish another great franchise was tragically missed. The fact that a major motion picture starring two Academy Award winners was made based on a handful of experimental cartoons that virtually no one saw is evidence of the opportunity.

Aeon Flux as created by Peter Chung achieved near cult status via a few late-night showings on MTV's "Liquid Television" in the early 1990's. That program may have represented the last gasp of the soul of MTV, now the Wal-Mart of teenage culture, complete with taking no chances at violating marketing results. One irony of Aeon Flux the film is MTV's logo in front of its own story (to avoid spoilers, I'll let you figure that one out, but suffice to say they are the bad guy, not the good guy).

Which brings us to the sadness: The good guys and bad guys. Which are obvious and formulaic--and not what Peter Chung created. Theron and Csokas as Aeon and Trevor, whether forced by the script or from lack of imagination, are not at all, in any way, by any stretch, the characters created by Chung. And Aeon Flux the animation drew interest and accolades almost entirely on those characters.

The success of the original Aeon Flux was based 25% on its ambiguousness and 75% on the personalities of its lead characters (though less as the series neared its end--again due primarily to lack of imagination and, sorry, simply balls on MTV's part).

Aeon and Trevor fascinate us specifically for their refusal to be driven by external purposes. Their stout resistance to the falsity of altruistic intentions and their adherence to their own ethic and interests is fresh and exciting, demonstrating what it would be like to be truly free of cultural and political hypnotism.

In the apparent darkest of times, they are the lightest of personal characters, with a spirit of play unachievable by those beholden to history, education and the machine of civilization.

The skill of adaptation is to capture essence. To recreate the emotional and intellectual response of the original in a new medium, regardless of physical trappings--witnessed by successful adaptations set in entirely different settings and circumstances.

All that was necessary to make Aeon Flux the film into a classic was to capture Aeon and Trevor's essence and deliver it, but no one associated with this film was interested in doing that.

review_title: Not Great. Not Terrible. Not Successful.
review_detailed_main:
One of the devices I used to keep myself entertained while watching Aeon Flux the movie was keeping a running total of the number of times I nodded off in the theater (7).

This film obviously fell short of the expectations of the general movie watching public and especially movie critics. Whether you were a fan of the animated series, or a fan of Theron, or a fan of good films, this film just does not serve any of these.

It's a bit flat, and the extended fight scenes were boring and served to confuse the whole point of the film. Was it a thoughtful science fiction film? Or was it a stylish action film? I would have liked to see it being more one or the other, rather than trying to appeal to the audience that thinks/feels, AND the audience that likes good action films. Not to say that you can't have a story with action AND a thoughtful storyline, but it appears Aeon Flux the movie failed because it is not enough of either.

Most people will be bored by this film, regardless of having an IQ that allows for an understanding of the "sub text." It's just a forgettable film that presents some interesting topics in a sort of half-as$ed way.

I could have excused the laid back, monotonous acting. I could have excused the poor casting of the lead. I could have excused the heavy handed direction and the writing. I could have excused almost anything bad about this film if it just had the quirkiness and strangeness that the original series had.

Don't look for oddly clever turns of common phrases from the original series ("That which doesn't kill us makes us stranger.")

Don't look for the odd and bizarre contraptions of the future.

Don't look for the irony.

Don't look for the very cool stuff from the animated series that the filmmakers chose to not exploit in making this film.

It's boring and it is forgettable.

review_title: Between the posing and the languid shots of beautiful people there is hint of a story.
review_detailed_main:
This is not a bad movie; it is not a great one either.

Between the posing and the languid shots of beautiful people (that's what the future gets ya ;-), there is hint of a story. The action is choreographed, feels at times uninspired and sometimes leaves you wondering...now why did the heroine go this way? Also missing was the feline grace of the classic Aeon, especially when approaching an objective.

After seeing Charlize in Monster, I know for sure that she can pull off the amoral, defiant and independent spirit of the classic Aeon Flux. Somehow the directing and the posing softened the new Aeon character too much. Looks like Charlize was not given much range and appeared to be reigned in as to not overshadow her fellow actors.

Casting is good enough, costume design and effects are very acceptable while not outstanding. Dialog on par with the range this movie allows. The fight scenes are entertaining but sometimes a bit predictable.

review_title: Lush and imaginatively sumptuous sci-fi, deliciously served
review_detailed_main:
Did you ever wish lycra-clad kick-boxing heroines could be a little more life like? How about a storyline where you lost the one you love with the hope of finding them 400 years (and many incarnations) in the future? Aeon Flux is a healthy dose of sci-fi fantasy for those who enjoy such things, distinct from Lara Croft or Matrix -type heroines (though you could also say derived from them if you are cynically non-futurist in your film tastes).

The multi-faceted Charlize Theron extends her athletic and ballerina skills to perform her own stunts in this beautifully realised (if fairly simplistic) tale of underground fighters (The Monicans) that are seeking to overthrow a dictatorship that is not always as benevolent as it would seem. After a deadly virus has struck down 99% of the world's population, the last surviving humans have been secretly cloned for many generations and exist in a seemingly perfect society. But people go missing. Monican Theron is given the mission to assassinate the leader but, as she penetrates the inner sanctums, she also penetrates plot layers revealing it to be far from a straightforward battle.

What makes Theron stand out is that she is very much all woman. Previous female superheroes have been masculine or androgynous ciphers played by a female lead in manga-like, sexless action sequences that reduce them almost to mindless puppets. Our heroine in Aeon Flux, in between high-tech fighting scenes, is unafraid to show subtle shades of emotion (one of the main plot lines depends on her interpreting her own feelings) or her passionate sexuality. (Those of you who recall the insipid 'sex' of the Matrix Trilogy must have wondered if future societies also demand all hormones be removed before any snogging occurs.) Neither are the eye-popping year 2415 technologies cine-standardised  they show a sensuous imagination: from the flowing futurescapes of Bregna city, ingestible telepathic liquids, subcutaneous communicators and biological gardens of defence weaponry flowers, Aeon Flux has a lushness that draws you in.

It's a pleasant change to have a sci-fi movie directed by a woman, with a woman's touch. Karyn Kusama has brought her feminine insight to what is all too frequently seen as a male genre and, as she did with Girlfight, imbued it with freshness and realism. Although the studio has emphasised its comic-strip provenance, this was probably ill-advised as comparisons fare poorly and the movie should be enjoyed as entertainment in its own right. You will probably know from the brief descriptions whether this is the sort of film for you - while Aeon Flux will hardly win over any new adherents, it is a joy for cult fans and one that will withstand repeated viewing.

This role accomplished two things for her: she managed to get people to realize she's not good looking, and that she sucks as an actress. But she wasn't the worst thing about this piece of crap movie. How could she be when one of the characters has HANDS for FEET. That really makes a lot of sense. I'm not even going to start on why that stupid idea wouldn't work. Then there's the killing and cloning because they can't reproduce, that the memories of the cloned people would be cloned with them, the ridiculous old guy in that gay costume on the flying turd where something, I think it's the cloning, takes place, and the moronic hit squad run by some red-haired musical theater reject.

Most of the bashing comes via comparisons to CATWOMAN (another bomb) or the fact that the original Æon Flux was an animated feature on MTV and the translation to live-action cinema didn't work. Not having seen these animated versions  or CATWOMAN for that matter  I can't make any comparisons. But what I can do is tell you how the movie flowed, how well it was acted, and its entertainment value.

Charlize Theron (NORTH COUNTRY) stars as Æon Flux, a rebel in the 25th century. A terrible disease has decimated humanity and its surviving members hide behind an enclosure, cut-off from the possible devastating effects of what lay beyond (think LOGAN'S RUN and you'll be close). Within the confines of their home live the remaining five million members of society thanks to the medical efforts of the Goodchild Regime, named after Trevor Goodchild (Martin Csokas). Æon Flux belongs to an elite group of resistance fighters known as the Monicans who's goal is to topple the Goodchild Regime. People have been vanishing. Police actions are resulting in deaths. And Æon Flux is going to find out why.

As we move through the stronghold of humanity (the city is known as Bregna), we learn and see much about this futuristic yet completely alien-like society. Pills can heighten awareness and even send coded messages to ones brain. Computers look like musical instruments or a type of String Theory. Everyone feels that something is wrong with their world ...and there is. Cloning and its effects on the power-base of the Goodchild Regime are holding humanity back at a terrible price.

CATWOMAN comparisons aside (yes, Charlize looks fantastic in her skin-tight leather outfit), this is a thinking person's film. There are lots of little tidbits thrown into the film that give it a futuristic look without trying too hard (the computers were a nice touch, as were filming many external shots in Berlin, Germany where new construction is the rage).

The pacing of the film was excellent. Never once did it get bogged down in the minutia of the times or the science. If you can't keep up, oh well. Leaping from action sequence to fight scene to action sequence made the 93 minutes fly by. The acting was okay. Nothing special but nothing horrible either. Charlize was the shining star, of course, and gave a relatively fine performance.

For my time, this was extremely entertaining and sexy, and full of great sci-fi scenery.

Only one question remains: What's up with the critics?!

review_title: Better than Ultraviolet, but that doesn't say much

Much of the blame can be laid at the door of director Karyn Kusama, who with this and JENNIFER'S BODY has proved herself to be adept at making trash. A lot of the film is let down by low-rent martial arts shenanigans that copy THE MATRIX trilogy and never once provide originality. At least EQUILIBRIUM's 'gun fu' was something we hadn't seen before...

The typically cold Charlize Theron plays a cold-hearted assassin who soon discovers that the world she lives in is built on a lie. As twists go, this one has the potential to be good, but somehow the reveal feels diluted, there isn't enough passion or surprise in the eventual discovery. It's more of a "oh, okay" type moment than a "wow" one.

The supporting cast isn't up to much either, with only Marton Csokas making an effort. Jonny Lee Miller is as inane as ever, and Sophie Okonedo is miscast and way out of her comfort zone. Watch out for Frances McDormand and Pete Postlethwaite in comedy cameo roles; I'm guessing they must have been desperate for the cash to appear in this knock-off. From beginning to end, AEON FLUX screams predictability and there's really no good reason to bother with it.

review_title: I really want to like this film but am sadly let down
review_detailed_main:
OK, I am not a movie critic but I felt compelled to write something here as I used the reviews on IMDb to determine whether or not to watch this movie. I stumbled across a reference to this film and without knowing anything about it or the cartoon, came to IMDb for an impartial viewpoint.

The acting is good and can't really be faulted and the story line I was happy with but it just seemed to crawl along and ended a little feebly. There was one point where I thought that it was about to get really interesting and I was excited about the rest of the movie (about half way in) but I was sadly let down as it sort of petered out with some odd action and a bland ending.

I haven't seen the cartoon so cannot comment on the comparison but what really let it down for me was the terrible editing. There were so many scenes (particularly the action scenes) where it just didn't add up. It was often as if the film was skipping forward 5 seconds as something would happen, and then some bizarre thing would occur. An example is where Aeon would be jumping through the air to land face down but suddenly it cut to her lying on her back. There were at least 5 occasions where this sort of thing was blatantly obvious. It just hacked me off as it seemed sloppy whereas a little extra care may have delivered the film in a nice slick package.

On a positive note the sets and outfits were great, the dialogue was a lot better than many films I have seen and the story on the whole was good but poorly executed. This could be one of those films that gets a cult following but for me, a guy who is usually tolerant of low budget productions, it was just sloppy execution for a $62m film.

I thought this was a lot like Underworld with Kate Beckinsale as the beautiful assassin but this doesn't hold a candle to Underworld in my opinion which I loved and have enjoyed many times. Both films are similar with Underworlds Gothic feel replaced with a quirky but likable futuristic aura. (Underworld budget $22m)

I give it a 5 as it was a good idea, it tries hard but poor editing was too much for me. Given a good re-edit I would perhaps give it 7.5 but 5 was all I could muster...give it a try if you get the opportunity but don't get too excited.

There were one or two minor characters I felt could have played a slightly larger role. The storyline is reasonably tight, in the mold of the classic sci-fi short story - the best kind for movies. review_title: Aeon should be in Zion with Neo
review_detailed_main:
Aeon Flux is the best assassin in a resistance group that operates against the rule of Trevor Goodchild, the leader of a government in a walled-up city. The city has been walled up to protect its citizens from a virus that nearly wiped out entire human race from the face of the earth.

When Aeon's sister, the only person she could really trust, dies instead of Aeon at the hands of soldiers working for Trevor Goodchild, her anger toward Trevor and his ruling of the city grows to the point where she can hardly wait to kill him. She finally gets that chance when the leader of the group Aeon works for assigns her to assassinate Trevor. But as she soon finds out, the things that she was taught to be true start to prove to be fabricated.

The movie offers some nice action scenes in the style of The Matrix and Equilibrium, but no scene registered to me even as remotely special. The script was so boring and dull, and it also seemed that too little is revealed about Aeon's past. She is the best assassin working for the Mohicans, but what made her to be that? Why does she do what she does? I can understand how she might have felt after her sister's death, but before that her intentions of working for the Mohicans is not clear.

All in all, Aeon Flux is another summer blockbuster that offers lots of eye candies but nothing more in categories of story, character development, etc. than its predecessors.

If you compare the rate of Aeon Flux (or e.g. Elektra) with those of almost every movie of recent years you realize how much fake rates are around. Every movie of the great studios or production companies of the last six or seven years with a lower a rate as 7+ is almost as rare as a deep blue two pence Mauritius stamp or a ice bear in the Mekong Delta. Anyway, Aeon Flux is far better than most of today's sci-fi action movies (with a few exceptions like The Edge of Tomorrow) - on top we get ueber-girl Charlize Theron, fine visuals, a good and interesting dystopian story and a fine production. That makes Aeon Flux one fine trip into some other version of Big Brother is watching you - not outstanding but still a fine piece to watch.

Problem: A big bunch of story from a series (ten times or so the running time of a movie) needs to be condensed into a easy-to-understand, entertaining 90min movie. Common Solutions: a)drop the series or b)overload the movie until it breaks down. Aeon Flux tries to go with both ways. It tames the series and especially the protagonist with kind of a new storyline. This leaves enough freedom in the story world for everyone to get along. But, for the b)-solution, it stumps the exposition into one solid block of story. The first 30 minutes (of approx. 85) are a nuisance of compressed, boiled down and abbreviated bits & pieces of information. This makes characters, plot and even the dystopian idea of the movie shallow and foreseeable. Therefore the script fails in the opening and nearly kills the whole movie with it. In addition, the dialogue and the camera work are cheesy and way too simple for the information the movie wants to give. Sentences like "Once I had a live,now I had a mission" should be forbidden and punished by the god of scripts himself. And for the camera: kidnapping victims do not drop red scarves in Technicolor and slow motion. This is not only simple, this is just cheap. And the cheap effect is sought fairly often, leading to the flat characters. My hand was already on its way to remote control, when suddenly á miracle happened: the movie started to flow. After 30 minutes or so (with the first meeting of Aeon and Goodchild), things started to roll. And from this point on it was like watching a different movie. Characters gained character, dialogs became entertaining, the action sequences were tense and gripping (despite a bunch of bad CGIs). Even the conventional MTV-camera style of the introduction found new ways and some excellent image compositions. Charlize Theron started to become credible as Aeon and Csokas enriched the movie greatly after his first real appearances with more then 3 sentences. Even the shallow (partly foreseeable) plot gained a bit of depth and found some better twists towards the end. Everything turned into a nice action sci-fi romp. My explanation for this extreme division of the movie would be that the writers and also the director knew that the series R.O.C.K.E.D. and had a clear vision about the "rocking" itself but they had a hard time developing the stage for the show. So it turns out to be a good action flick in the end but falls flat on any larger scale and has its harsh shortcomings in structure and substance. The recommendation for a excellent adaption of a sci-fi series to the big screen still is Serenity. And the best Dystopia with a low budget still is Equilibrium. This is only too bad. The potential had been there to come up with something really innovative. But finances might have played a part in this, too. The movie has a hard time to shake off a "sci-fi Xena"-TV double episode charm. With a bigger budget for a better production and 30 minutes more to develop in senseful manner this could have been a great movie. As it is now, it is just a slightly above average mainstream movie. You can watch it, you don't need to watch it.

review_detailed_main:
I was very excited to hear Aeon Flux was being made a while back because I am a fan of the show. I was so excited I kept tabs on its production throughout the year. When I saw the trailer though, I was shocked. There were some really cheesy and cliché action-flick lines in the trailer and the only glimpse of her acrobatics was her crawling, rather slowly, across the grass. I thought it was going to be horrible, not including the fact that her costume and hair (for a while I was angered her hair wasn't the same as the shows, but after watching it, I think it looks fine) were completely different. The trailer made me believe it was going to be full of corniness like "Catwoman." Nevertheless, I wanted to fully see how it would turn out because the behind-the-scenes footage looked decent. I was surprised when I saw the film.

It was visually stunning. I was happy they decided to deviate from the dark, urban looking future that defines many sci-fi films like "the Matrix" and "Blade Runner" (not because I was going to compare it to "the Matrix" as many people now mistakenly call movies with saturated colors and black clothing "Matrix ripoffs"... that's been done forever, "the Matrix" isn't the only one). It's pretty colorful and fresh-looking, somewhat like the setting of the show (okay, okay, the movie is more colorful than the show, but it's still 'new'). Charlize's acrobatics are very good. Very graceful. When Kusama, in the behind-the-scenes footage online said Charlize is very a very graceful actress, physically, I was a bit hesitant to agree... but when I saw the film, my doubts were shattered... it was pretty darn good for a live action film. Her bendy flips and all of that were very Aeon-like. Very very impressive.

The story was okay. It did dwell one some interesting current issues, but the timing of the film makes it look like 'it's been done'. (Following other sci-fi films like the Island and Gattaca.) I wish it could have been released earlier... Even so I liked how the story itself included many elements of the show. Even little nuances like the "tongue passing pill" kiss scene...(that's in the trailer) I recognized that from Gravity... if I remember correctly...

Character development, like others have mention, is pretty minimal. I thought Kusama could have done a better job with this as there is lot of movie time left (this is only something like an hour and a half... could have stretched it long like "Batman Begins")... but I'm not so sure. Granted, there could have been a pacing problem if the story was stretched longer. Anyway, the parts where there were attempts to develop character were glaringly obvious. There would be a line or two passed between characters and you feel like there should be a bit more behind it... or you wish for it...

Aeon's character has been a little sexed-down unfortunately (I'm a girl, but I thought the overt sexuality of the show/personality made Aeon much more interesting)... but there are little hints of her 'former'-self, I guess you could say. They throw in a line/action or two. She's also made a little more human... I think that was done to attract a wider audience though... sometimes her ruthlessness in the show was unexplained, but seemingly allowable... This might not have worked for the film.

But even so, this is a pretty fast paced, artsy action film. I really enjoyed it. It does seem pretty shallow but it stands out from other stupid superhero/sci-fi films that have come out lately like "Fantastic Four". It is even and maintains a constant theme/tone and the combination of story/issue elements make it unique... much like the show. Unfortunately there isn't too much of Aeon hard-hitting dark humor (although what there is, is pretty funny ^^), but it's still enjoyable. I think it's worth your $10 bucks, or whatever you pay to see a movie. Even if the story doesn't excite you, at least the weirdness and "What the f*** just happened?/is that?" factor (also from the show) will keep you there.

What I don't get is why they didn't let critics comment/preview it... I agree with Ebert/Roeper (just saw the show today :P) that even the preview looks better than a lot of other similar films out there... anyhoo, guess we'll never know why they chose not to do so...

--Oh yeah I also enjoyed the Stuart Townsend cameo (Charlize's boyfriend... or is it fiancé?)... I'm a big fan of his too :)... Although his spiked hair and black eye were not very flattering... :P--

review_title: All right homage to show, but not a perfect interpretation, and weak as a stand-alone feature
review_detailed_main:
Okay, I saw "Aeon" last night, and I found the movie to be more of an homage to the series, itself, than a true stand-alone feature. It seemed to me like the writers just plucked as many names and gadgets from individual episodes as they could, and laid them upon a skeleton of a storyline. As a fan, I appreciate that, as the series has been largely ignored post-cancellation, but to the general movie-going public, I can see why it would seem to be a sub-par feature.

As far as my problems with character translation, my biggest gripe is with the writers' interpretation of Trevor. In the series, he was quite methodical and quite full of himself, though he did have a tender and compassionate side to him. I felt the film version of Trevor was far too soft and innocent.

I wasn't completely satisfied with Aeon, either. I felt that the film version was far more idealistic than the animated one. During the show, Aeon was an anarchist, out only for herself and only occasionally humanity. Here, she seemed to be more of humanity's great champion, out to avenge the wrongs done by the Goodchild regime. Plus, her relationship with Trevor during the show was far more contentious and love/hate than it was in the film.

I thought Theron's performance as Aeon was passable, and I do appreciate her working so hard, both physically and mentally, to do her best at portraying Aeon; but, with such a weak script, I wasn't impressed. As Trevor said in one episode, "I know cats always land on their feet, but at this point, there's really no floor."

Perhaps if the writers had more closely followed the original subject matter, the movie would have been more compelling. However, in its current state, the film is, at best, an all right homage to the show. At the very least, it spurred MTV to finally release the balance of the series on DVD and heightened the public's interest in Peter Chung's work. As an "Aeon" fan, I give the film a 5/10.

review_title: A plot-driven, de-sexed version of a plot-less, sexy animation
review_detailed_main:
The key to enjoying this film is not to compare it to the original animation. Aside from the names of the characters and 1 or 2 nods to the cartoon (like the opening sequence of a fly in the eyelashes), there is very little in common between the two.

The original animation was a very expressionistic piece of art, without dialogue, often without any plot, and with distorted perspectives of reality. This film, in the opposite corner, has an strong plot, a good bit of dialogue and a relatively realistic presentation. I can understand the cartoon fans' outrage, but I believe a faithful film adaptation would've been impossible unless you got someone like Fellini to direct it, and then the audience would hate it because it wouldn't make sense. On top of that, you'd need a silicone-enhanced porn star to take the leading role because I doubt anyone else would agree to do gymnastics while wearing a thong the size of a postage stamp.

In other words, if a film had to be made about Aeon Flux, they might as well go in the opposite direction which is what they did here. As I said, this is a very plot-driven story, clever and at times philosophical with the theme of nature vs. science, or perhaps you could see it as chaos vs. order (Werner Herzog would be thrilled). If it were slowed down and extended an hour or two, I think this would've made a fantastic Kubrickian mindbender à la "2001: A Space Odyssey", but instead they went for a more general audience by making Aeon Flux an action flick. No gripes there; there's plenty of action to keep you from snoozing, and the special effects, while being computer generated, are not obnoxiously so.

My biggest gripe is that it was far too conservative in the costumes department. Aeon's whole identity (in the animation) was based on her overflowing sexuality even though she was a somewhat androgynous personality. Charlize Theron achieved the somewhat androgynous personality, but the visual sexuality was lacking because they had her dressed up in what looked like a scuba suit most of the time. So I guess I and a whole generation of at-the-time-prepubescent-teen-boys will have to go watch our VHS copy of Barbarella for our dose of intergalactic smut. Drat.

Aeon Flux presents a somewhat de-sexed, female action hero which itself is a novelty. My guess is that the director purposely did it this way, perhaps to achieve a level of believability that you can't get when your star is wearing a postage stamp. In the spirit of the original Bionic Woman TV series of the 70s which had a hot actress but didn't sink to showing skin & gratuitous cheesecake, we have the same thing here with Charlize Theron. I think she pulled it off brilliantly. A very entertaining flick.

Post-apocalyptic future 2415, and 99% of the Earth's population has been wiped out, victims to a virus that struck in 2011. What survivors there are now reside in Bregna, a walled city state which is ruled by a collective of scientists. An apparent safe nirvana on the surface, Bregna is however beset with problems. Enter the Monicans, an underground rebel organisation who communicate telepathically and follow orders given by The Handler. When Æon Flux (Theron), a Monican agent, is given a mission to assassinate Trevor Goodchild (Csokas), the last surviving government leader of the human state, she discovers the sad truth about humanity's survival.

Yes there's some dazzle effects work for the undemanding, and yes, Theron is lithe, athletic and sexy in the lead role; even if she looks totally miserable and lacking emotional gravitas for the character as written. But with clunky dialogue permeating the narrative and the likes of Postlethwaite and McDormand miscast and ridiculous, this is an expensive futuristic stinking flop. 3/10

Like Frances McDormand's hair in this film this opinion piece is all over the place The comic adaptation of Peter Chung's Aeon Flux TV series is a mixed blessing of a movie. There is much to love about it, and there is much to hate about it and the two cancel each other out.

The plot has Aeon Flux trying to kill the leader of the surviving band of humans in a virus ravaged earth. The plot itself is rather straight forward even if the details are needlessly obscured. The whys and hows are all there if you're willing to wade through the violence and form over substance sequences, the question is are you going to be awake at the end to hear the denouncement? The problem in a nutshell is that this film wants to be all things to all people, it wants to copy the source material but be its own film; it wants to be big and showy and have an intimate sci-fi story at its heart; it wants to be weird and cutting edge, yet wants to be normal. It looks like it was designed together sequence by sequence by committee and then given to the director to fit together. It doesn't work, or rather it works in pieces but not as a whole.

I can't really recommend the film, but I can't discount that undemanding sci-fi fans who like less than clear musings might like it. 4 out of 10 instead of 5 simply because I can't say try it...maybe its a 4.8, I don't know, maybe worth a shot on cable

Just got back from the movie. Full disclosure: I'm a fan of the Liquid Television/MTV show, and will be looking at the film in this context.

The film eschews most of the dangerous aspects of Cheung's Aeon while the new material represents a classic "closed loop" story, or for McKee followers, story rather than anti-story. The biotech stuff is intriguing conceptually, but the execution is so pedestrian that none of it grabs you (I'll give a nod to Trevor's pollen as an exception). The clean look of the production design is matched by a very safe, bright photography that makes for a sterility that, while helpful in underscoring the notion of an over-controlled utopia, looks simple and more to the point completely reverses the "lived in" grime of the original animated universe. It will lose nothing going to DVD because there is so little detail anywhere.

The sexual aspect never had to be explicit, but it did need to have some shock or kink value to have any faithfulness to the original, easily accomplished within PG-13 constraints through innuendo - they took a pass on it. Amazing that the trailer for "Underworld: Evolution" which screened before the film made me think "Aeon" more that the film of the name (Ms. Beckinsale just has more taunt in her)!

This is a safe, linear narrative, when it should have been treated like a cross between film- noir and one of David Lynch's less accessible films. They did good by not making Trevor a villain, but they blew it by making him and Aeon heroes (and what happened to Trevor's narcissism?). WTF? Aeon Flux was a capricious conniving I-can't-even-say-it! The old Aeon did the right thing only when she thwarted those doing wrong, but the shoe was on the other foot more then once. In Aeon's world, tragedy should trump hope, and the flaw should be both Aeon and Trevor's, not palmed off on some fabricated straw man like the brother.

In closing: where's the ugliness? Hell even Aeon's vixen-self was contorted into grotesquerie half the time in the old days. Repellent fascination? This movie was neither repellent nor fascinating. Ms. Theron is undeniably beautiful, and has proved her ability elsewhere, but despite some creditable action sequences, and solid production values all-around, Karen Kusama doesn't seem to have much command of tone or mood, and this project needed to be drenched in both to call itself Aeon Flux. I should need a bath afterwords, instead I'm going out for a drink to wash the clean off.

Such a stylish film. At first I just focused on the art direction, the look was so in-your-face and consistently fresh and brilliant. Gradually the characters and plot lines began to mesh into a coherent whole. This was actually about something and definitely not predictable. Even the art direction continued to evolve by stages, from a very California look to a distinctly European feel. Every shot very beautiful, nature never very far away.

A thriller/scifi with mostly women in the action parts. How unusual. A woman producer and a woman director. And a story line with very contemporary themes we're all thinking about, anticipating in the very near future -- massive species killing diseases, cloning as a commonplace reality, the dream of denying death and what that might mean.

Get this dialogue:

He: The cloning is all we have. If you do this, we end. She: We're meant to die. It's what makes anything about us matter. Nothing like this torture.

With lesser actors, lesser art direction and if placed at the beginning instead of, as here, at the summation, those same lines would be stilted groaners. In context, they actually say something.

Loved it. Now I realize why it got such good reviews from the serious press. I'm looking forward to seeing it again with the commentaries.

review_title: Oh dear miss Theron, from Monster to this?
review_detailed_main:
Critics have started calling it the Oscar Winner club, understandably. What after Halle Berry won it for Monsters Ball then going straight to the diabolical Catwoman. Hilary Swank triumphs in Boys Don't Cry and follows it with The Core. Jamie Foxx takes a nosedive as a pilot in the dull Stealth after scooping a gong for Ray. Now it's seems Hollywood Starlet Charlize Theron craps all over her "Monster" Oscar with this one of the worst Sci-fi spectacles ever made.

The film loses its audience interest after a mere 20 minutes meaning the only thing really worth staying for is the fact that despite the film being rubbish Charlize Theron is still an exceptional actress who is clearly making the best of a crude and laughable premise. Not only is Æon Flux ultimately shallow but for an action flick it's also really very dull. It will only really appeal to comic book fans and Horney teenagers who like the idea of Theron running around half naked for 90 minutes. Flux only really succeed in failing.

Set against the 2011 virus that kills 99% of the world's populace, and in the last city on Earth, Bregna, the survivors, some four hundred years later, in the year 2415, are continuing to live in the Goodchild dynasty, the name of the scientist who developed its cure.

All is not well in this utopia and it is not what lies beyond its high walls that protects its citizens from the never ending jungle but what unspoken, unwritten taboo that holds and binds these unwritten taboo that holds and binds these unfortunates' together that lies within these walls of paranoia, conformity and unquestionable obedience. Filmed in and around Berlin, ironically, this is a story set against a totalitarian state, a walled city, where its peoples are no longer capable of reproducing, and its sinister and most secret plot of how it sustains life.

Æon Flux is the assassin that has been assigned by the underground rebels to change the course of Mankind, forever. This is the story of her fight for justice, freedom and revenge.

Æon Flux combined lousy narratives, ropy pacing and truly dire effects. Looking more like an unrealistic video game rather than a film. The only thing that is fortunate about the failure is that no sequels are in the works, Flux might just be the beginning and the end of what could have been one of the worst franchises in history, thank god for the lousy box office takings then.

My final verdict on this truly lousy feature? There really isn't a story here just Charlize Theron jumping around in a black suit like a grass hopper. The acting is very wooden moronic and emotionless compared to the other cinemas that are out there today. review_title: What in the world were they thinking?

review_detailed_main:
I, for one, have not watched the series before arriving at the theatre, so I knew nothing of the story before watching it. The design of the sets whetted my appetite, hinting at an intricate interaction between the characters and their environment, joined by a gripping background story. Unfortunately, the next hour of movie-watching destroyed my hopes and left me more than mildly annoyed.

First to crush my hopes was the acting or, more accurately, the lack thereof. I could not associate with any of the characters but, apparently, neither could the actors. They lacked the usual passion, ambition, or sense of urgency that you usually expect from lead characters in an action film. They were casually talking to each other about their beliefs as if discussing their dinner preferences. Neither boons nor catastrophes could penetrate their veil of detachment. Consequently, I was wholly detached from anything they did.

Next was the script. I was not able to suspend my disbelief enough to ignore the glaring scientific (and algebraic) mistakes. (So much for hoping that script writers know how to use a calculator.) I am always negatively impressed by those who manage to contradict what I learned in my Biology, Physics, and Math classes. My impression is, unfortunately, long-lasting.

I wasn't as much disappointed by the action--but that was because most of today's films take shortcuts to choreographing fight sequences and zoom in while shaking the camera, zooming out suddenly to reveal the foes' defeat, leaving us wondering what had happened. I've grown desensitized to bad fight scenes, but not to inelegant (needless, explicit) violence, which seemed to have been added as an afterthought.

However, the saving grace of the film was the design, and it is solely the design that prompted me to rate this film 7/10. Camera-wise, the film crew created a pleasing film (aside from the fighting). The outfits, although cliché, were interesting and clever; the buildings were pretty; the hairstyles were sharp. A small world had been constructed quite carefully in order to make this film. The designers did not take the future for granted: watch carefully to discern a whole new culture portrayed by recreating everyday commodities. This portrayal made it possible to accept such a view of the future, and accept that it actually /is/ the future.

Ironically, it is the design that left me most disappointed. The fantastic world ended up being but an empty shell without a story or characters to fill it. I was yearning for some other director to run off with the sets and fill them with another story; for some fans to re-dub the film and make it more appealing. All in all, the film to me was a showcase of imagination, unfortunately filled with actors who, even more unfortunately, spoke.

review_title: I just wanted to see Charlize Theron and expected nothing more...and for the most part, that's exactly what I got.
review_detailed_main:
It's true, the only reason why I wanted to see this was because I just wanted to see Charlize Theron bounce around in her black latex outfit. I expected nothing. I didn't expect this to be a faithful adaptation of the 1995 MTV Oddity TV show (which is an interesting show, must see!), I didn't expect it to be a worthy addition to the Aeon Flux universe, and hell...I didn't expect it to be any good.

Charlize Theron was the only reason why I plucked down $5.25 for the movie ticket. And for the most part, it was worth it. However, the movie itself did surprise me pretty well because of my low expectations.

To sum it up, the entire beginning of the film is very slow and boring. The only real characters that are developed throughout the entire film are just Aeon and Trevor, which I thought they did a real good job near the end of the film. Everyone else either can't act or weren't THAT critical to the plot and character development as much as they should've been, which made them sort of worthless.

But when that lil' ol' plot twist kicks in, the film suddenly becomes a lot more interesting which is both a good and bad thing. Good because my $5.25 was actually being paid off for something other than Charlize Theron and Bad because it took over an hour for the film to become interesting and worth that $5.25. What the plot twist is, well...find out for yourself, through the movie or from other people's spoiler reviews. I thought it was implemented pretty well.

As far as any of the action and special effects featured here, very few things are as spectacular as the trailer made the film out to be. The hand-to-hand fighting is like what I saw in the Chronicles of Riddick and Batman Begins, the camera angles were zoomed in and abruptly edited up to the point you can't see what's going on and ultimately becomes unsatisfactory. They should've hired better choreographers and camera men who don't have Parkinson's disease, then the fight scenes would've probably been actually viewable and maybe a little more entertaining to watch.

The special effects, however, were not that bad. Very few (like what was in the trailer) were impressive to look at while everything else was iffy. Most of the time the director will try to impress you with presenting a prettied up scene with a certain camera angle to try to give it a "unique" feel, but that effect only works 15-20% of the time while the rest of the 80-85% give you a cliché and rushed feeling, like you've seen it before or they're trying WAAAAAAAY too hard to impress you. The actual design of the sets and costumes were mediocre as well, they tried to do a "Fifth Element meets Equilibrium" with the Aeon Flux-style and ended up making something that's just plain odd to look at. And not odd in a unique and interesting way, odd in a blandish kinda way. They could've added more than just a few vibrant colors to bring the Aeon Flux world to life, but I give them credit for what they did do (the marble scene was one of the more impressive scenes in the entire movie).

But despite these major gripes, the movie didn't really suck as much as I anticipated. The plot twists were enjoyable, the two main characters are great to watch once you get accustomed to them, and overall it's not that bad of a movie. It's nothing special, nothing real noteworthy, but it's entertaining nonetheless. Plus with Charlize Theron gracing some type of skin tight black outfit throughout the entire film pretty much, you really can't go wrong.

review_title: Kept from critics for good reason.
All the looks of a sci-fi classic, but the story doesn't match up
review_detailed_main:
Based on all the (almost exclusively) bad reviews I'd seen of this movie beforehand, Aeon Flux was quite a positive surprise. First let me say that it really helps to be familiar with the cartoon series. Otherwise a bunch of things won't make sense. And the movie does neglect to explain just what "Monicans" are, and it makes no mention that I noticed of the country of Monica. In fact, the portrayal of the world in which the action took place was not as detailed as it ought to have been. A major point of the cartoon show was the trans-humanism of such a future; that people could have all sorts of weird bio-cyber-things implanted. In the movie, all we really see of this is the hand-feet of Aeon's sidekick (and that "meeting-in-the-mind" thing). We should have been shown how this sort of thing was integrated into all levels of society. Unless of course the movie world was different than the cartoon world, which sadly takes a lot of the edge off of the concept. So that was one thing they should have done better. Maybe there'll be a director's cut with more details. I'd buy that.

The action that made it into the movie looked superb. The landscapes, architecture, general design, etc., and the characters' moves during the action scenes were amazing. I have only seen a small handful of Charlize Theron movies before, but this is definitely the movie where I enjoyed her the most. Perfect, long-legged, athletic agility, and an amazing face. And gorgeous costumes. Eye-candy of the highest order, and that's what mainly serves to recommend the movie.

The story, unfortunately, disappointed. It was very interesting up until the clone revelation. There was this device that could transfer a person between locations, looking like it peeled off a layer of reality. And since that Goodchild character had said that nothing is as it seems, I was expecting some ontological point, akin to Matrix or Stanislaw Lem's Futurological Congress, where reality is an illusion caused by certain chemicals in the air. Couple that with the strange rebirth of Aeon's sister, making us think that there was some kind of transfer of consciousness going on, or a form of bona-fide reincarnation. With that kind of expectations in mind, you can imagine what a massive let-down it was to learn that it was all about the people being cloned (and no, there were no transfer of consciousness, just the DNA). After the recent Star Wars movies and the bomb that was The Island, a plot involving clones would have to be pretty DAMN good in order to have any real originality or entertainment value. Here it was just anti-climactic. A big downer.

And it's worse than that. The whole Goodchild Tyranny does not make sense. If they have cloning technology, there's a million ways they could use it. To me, the clone revelation just doesn't work at all as an explanation for the effective perpetuation of that society.

So overall Aeon Flux was an opportunity wasted (yeah, another one of those coming out of Hollywood; tragically they're the rule rather than the exception), but at least it looked damn good in the overall design and the action scenes, so I'm rating the movie higher than the story deserves.

6 out of 10.

review_title: This movie was almost a disappointment
review_detailed_main:
I'll start off by saying that there isn't much about the animated series of Aeon Flux that I remember. I watched it maybe two or three times in my life and then thought little of it later on. But for some reason, when I saw the previews for this film, I had the desire to see it. So keep in mind, this is a review coming from a person who really hasn't seen the show enough times to draw any conclusions based on comparisons. I want to review Aeon Flux as a stand alone film.

Aeon Flux is a beautifully crafted film. The environments are sleek and imaginative, and the people have a futuristic style that is clever and not cliché. The action scenes manage to tickle your senses--most of the time. The choice of camera angles is also impressive, and it's good to see in a generation of action films heavily influenced by The Matrix films. Bullet-time is old. Although Aeon Flux doesn't set any new standards for action films like the underestimated "Domino" should have, it is still a visually encompassing movie to watch. One might argue that this isn't necessarily an action film either. Aeon Flux does have a decent story.

If you manage to sit through the first hour of the film, you will come to appreciate the visuals and the story. Aeon Flux spends a lot of time setting the viewer up for the plot, which at first, seems to be a bit forced and convoluted. The viewer will be left in a state of confusion as to what's going on. Add that to a series of redundant scenes and you might find yourself falling asleep if you see the late-night show...or joking around with friends like I was. I even was tempted to walk out. But if you have the patience, you will see this movie reveal it's brilliant plot and a collection of themes that inspire plenty of critical thinking. Too bad it ends thirty minutes later. The film is short, and you will be left stunned when you realize the movie is about to end, even though Aeon claims that there is still more to do. Nonetheless, the film has an edge of your seat ending with a bit of emotion as well, something the film doesn't convey in the beginning.

Purists may be very disappointed. Newcomers with closed-minds will also be disappointed. But Aeon Flux is a movie that will keep you thinking about it for a few more days after you see it, and now I want to see the TV series. It might help me appreciate the movie even more, or in turn, it may not. Take a risk, go see this at the theaters.
