review_title: Great effects are ruined by flat, dull characters, making Aeon Flux a slight letdown.
review_detailed_main:
It's aim was to become this year's "The Matrix". But it unfortunately failed and ended up as a bit of a sham. Great settings and fight sequences were marred by perhaps the flattest, dullest performances this year, a poor ending, lack of character and substance in the script and unnecessary betrayals of the characters. None of the actors delivered particularly memorable performances (save the Keeper guy, who was old and dressed in a weird suit, whose eerie deliveries made his performances pretty good), and Trevor Goodchild was so unbelievably dull and forgettable that the bloke who played him should be shot. This film has great ideas, but they need to be entwined well into the story, unlike on this film. Along with a total lack of any character, you really don't identify with any of them, including Aeon, and by the end of the film, you don't really care whether they live or die. It just didn't have character, like "I, Robot", and lacked hugely in substance and suspense, like "The Matrix". This film should have been so much better. It may have had an Oscar winning lead actor and an evidently big budget, but it really didn't cut the cheese, and ended up as a rather sub-par action flick. The fact that a virus killed 99% of the world's population was revealed in a way that shows that nobody really cared about that and just wanted to get on with the eye candy scenes.

But there are also good things about this film. It is without a doubt stunning to look at, and includes fight sequences that surpass even those of "The Matrix" in skills and thrills. A little-known director has done a truly huge achievement in these amazing fights. And the effects are amazing, and the film will not bore you in any way. However, there should have been more action sequences, and they were slightly over-the-top in parts. But this only makes it better. However, the movie-going public want more than just carnage - they want meaning and talent in their films, and aside the beautiful looks, there really is little else to be offered by this film. The boring, rubbish performances and repetitive, inexperienced script hamper a film that could have been great.

It would be wrong to call this film a disaster of epic proportions - it is a beautifully made and put together film, with a fast pace and great fights. But if the actors had actually cared about their roles, thus making us care more for them, this film could have been better. Much better. This film is not going to win Charlize Theron her second Oscar, and it certainly won't get the bloke who played Trevor Goodchild any offers - he was absolute doggy-dos in this film. He didn't care when his life disappeared before his eyes. On the whole - Aeon Flux is a definite one to be reckoned with in eye-candy terms, but in terms of depth and character, it fails to engage. 5/10

In the futuristic year of 2415, a deadly virus has left Earth with a population of only about five million. They live in a seemingly Utopia city called Bregna. If you're familiar with these sort of stories, you'll figure there is a resistance group, who live outside the society; in this case, they are the Monicans. From this underground, tightly-clad beauty Charlize Theron (as Æon Flux) is sent to assassinate Bregna leader Marton Csokas (as Trevor Goodchild). His brother Jonny Lee Miller (as Oren Goodchild) is another power broker, and Ms. Theron's preferred partner is Sophie Okonedo (as Sithandra)...

This was based on an imaginative MTV series of short films, which seemed like it would make a great feature. The addition of a brother (Mr. Miller's Goodchild) is good, and promises more intrigue - but the four main characters are only given conventional plot lines. The four have a tense and deadly confrontation, and have to play it without proper buildup. Probably, they should have had original writer Peter Chung become more involved with the feature's script. It might have been interesting, also, for director Karyn Kusama and her crew to shoot this as a non-verbal. It's got great geometry.

***** Æon Flux (12/1/05) Karyn Kusama ~ Charlize Theron, Marton Csokas, Jonny Lee Miller, Sophie Okonedo

review_title: A fair but not bad Sci-Fi Film
review_detailed_main:
Way back in the 90s MTV ran a nice little cartoon series call Aeon Flux where we were in a future where most people are dead and the military rules with an iron hand. Aeon is the scantly clad people's hero constantly fighting against the evils of chairman Goodchild who is sometimes even on her side. Of course there is a lot of fighting and a lot of death.

Well now we are in the age of the new Aeon Flux which is all live action and a slight bit different. This one takes place in the future with very few surviving people where many are mysteriously disappearing. A group of rebels called the Monocans are trying to assassinate the leader of the ruling group (Trevor Goodchild). Well things get quite complicated as they don't go as planned and thus the fun begins.

Aeon Flux is a futuristic movie that is quite different from many other future type movies in the sense that the background seems quite different and the feel is different. Unfortunately it doesn't quite have the same feel as the Animated series. The Plot is a fairly decent one and it makes for a fun movie. The Acting quality isn't overly good but not terrible either. Visually it is by far the most pleasing aspect as the architecture and costume design are very well done. As far as Sci-Fi Action Pieces Go Aeon Flux is a fairly good film but nothing to run out and buy.

review_title: OK tale of a supposed perfect future world...
review_detailed_main: 1st watched 8/6/2006 - 5 out of 10(Dir-Karyn Kusama): OK tale of a supposed perfect future world with rebels like Aeon Flux trying to prove otherwise. Aeon, played by Charlize Theron, is charged to remove the power at hand, Chairman Trevor Goodchild, played well by Martin Csokas, but is unable to do so and starts to learn more about herself, her past and the truth of what the current world consists of while hanging out with Mr. Goodchild. Things become more complex when a power-hungry brother tries to remove the current Chairman so he can reign and the rebels start hunting Aeon sensing that she's defected to the other side. There is some nice sets of the colorful new world and a story that keeps you interested, but Theron doesn't seem suited for this type of role and her weakness in the lead smothers what could have been a good movie. A well-intentioned attempt is made to make the story more important than the action but it doesn't quite give us enough to hold the movie together as a complete entity.

Among other user comments that do not rave, but give a nodding acceptance to another action movie, my comment won't stand out as raving about how delicious it was, or that I hate it either. This is another middle of the road movie your going to see on peoples shelves from time to time, if they like Theron.

Strengths: Nice Flow of events. The plot truly unraveled without becoming to stagnate, predictable, or confusing. After the first major plot twist I found myself predicting it wouldn't be the last. I'm never wrong. There are also decent special effects. You won't find any cheesy Catwoman/Blade2 computer crapola. Also my date enjoyed it, so that's a plus.

Weaknesses: Where's the in depth character progression? I found myself unable to relate to main characters that were having life altering revelations. Who are these people? The intro was one like Underworld's brief narrated one. However, Underworld had one redeeming characteristic that this movie falls entire to short of. Kate Beckinsale wrapped in the most seductive skin tight leather I've ever seen. Theron's outfit made her shoulders look broad and wasn't the eye candy I was hoping for. There's really nothing to come back to see. Other than the plot, this movie is just a run of the mill action.
And that was all i could bear. Just an unwatchable movie made for people with chewing gum in their brains.

Being a fan of the Aeon Flux Animation shorts and series. I was hoping that Hollywood wouldn't blow this one. I no longer go into movies that were taken from Comic books, Graphic Novels, Animations, or Video Games with high expectations because I have had really high expectations previously only to be disappointed, then later came to the conclusion that some of the movies were actually pretty good, just not as good as they could have been. So I didn't go into this one with high expectations, I was just hoping they wouldn't blow it, but they did blow it. They took an original edgy intriguing story and characters and homogenized it into some mythical commercial movie template. They tried to turn the push/pull relationship between Aeon, and Trevor Goodchild(the villain in the Animation)into a 'love story' and Devillianized Trevor. They made up the envious little brother as the bad guy and put Trevor as a victim They also changed other things for no apparent reason like no monitors, instead everything is reflected on water? WHY? the weapons when Aeon and Sathandra were changed from mechanical to biological? The movies was 'mainstreamed' enough from the original animation to make it not nearly as interesting as the the original Animation, leaving a hum drum sci-fi that doesn't really peak the interest of the Sci-Fi fans, and certainly didn't capture the interests of the mainstream movie go'ers(reflected in the fact it was a 30 million dollar loser at the box office). I kept waiting for it to get really good but it just never did. Congratulations Hollywood on blowing another good story.

This is what happens when you take a great original edgy SCI-FI story and 'change it to be more mainstream' you alienate the SCI-FI genre fans, the Aeon Flux Fans, and you failed to capture mainstream appeal, Congratulations to the producer/director/writers you blew it on all accounts.

Now normally here I would write a quick little summary about what the movie was about. However, the plot line was so scattered and nonsensical that I can't even begin to attempt to salvage anything from that movie. It was terrible, my friends and I just shook our heads throughout the entire movie. There were more plot holes in this movie than Swiss cheese. I really gave this movie my best attempts at following the story, but I gave up fairly quickly.

I'll give it credit that there were a few good parts. Some parts were actually cool. And Charlize is a stunningly beautiful woman who wore very sexy outfits indeed. But she is better than this movie.

And so are all of you. Please don't go see it. Ever. Unless someone hands it to you for free and you have an hour and a half of your life to throw away.

review_title: All Dressed Up With Nowhere To go
review_detailed_main:
I saw the movie on opening day (last Friday). I see that a lot of people have already keyed in on many of the points I wanted to make, so I'll only touch lightly on those and focus on some others.

The production values were great.

The cast was great.

The special effects were great.

It's worth seeing the movie once on a big screen just to take in those aspects of it. It's a technical marvel.

The overall movie, however, was skeletal. There was very little meat in this movie.

The TV series was this way, too. But the TV series worked because in each episode, we were treated to various non sequitur sights of weird technology or odd behaviors (remember the disclaimer that always came on before each episode?) which filled in the gaps in the otherwise simple plot for the episode.

The movie treats us to a few of these non sequiturs, but mostly on the technological side, not on the behavioral side. They needed to inject a lot more of both in order to fill in the gaps in the story. It would have made the movie work a lot better. The same trick that made the series work would have made the movie work, too.

As a true "Aeon Flux" fan, I was expecting a lot of the non sequiturs in this movie, and I was left feeling empty when I walked out.

If I had to guess, I would say that the makers of the movie got scared and erred on the side of conservatism when translating the story from the animated TV version to the live action movie version. The movie version tries too hard to explain Aeon's world and circumstances in concrete terms. The TV series just presented her world and left it up to the viewer to take it all in and make sense of it.

To sum it all up: Unrealized potential.

review_title: Aeon Flux Much Less than Sum of its Parts
review_detailed_main:
Aeon Flux is set some 400 years in the future, long after a 2011 plague decimates virtually the entire population of the planet Earth. Only a last minute cure has saved any of humanity. Earth's one remaining city  Bregna  is perfectly landscaped. Its citizens are uniformly well taken care of. And yet there's ugliness beneath the surface as the government itself is suspected of kidnapping and worse.

A secret group of rebels calling themselves Monicans is working to both mitigate and expose government wrongdoing. Among the Monicans' most stalwart and skilled operatives is Aeon Flux (Charlize Theron). Though she maintains some semblance of normalcy as she visits with her sister, Una (Amelia Warner), she's also covertly in contact with her Monican "handler" (Frances McDormond). As she completes yet another assignment successfully, she returns to her usual life only to find tragedy has struck in her absence.

Now angrier than ever, Aeon is grimly satisfied to get her next assignment: the assassination of government head, Chairman Trevor Goodchild (Martin Czokas). Along with his brother, Oren (Jonny Lee Miller) and a small committee of others, Goodchild maintains the walled city with an iron fist. While most don't even know enough to question the beneficence of the government, Aeon and the other Monicans know too much.

In short order, Aeon finds herself a partner (Sithandra, played by Sophie Okonedo) headed into the very seat of government. Overcoming the many security measures of the complex, however, turns out to be less of a problem than the knowledge not everything is as it seems. When some of Aeon's most worrisome questions are finally answered by a man known only as The Keeper (Pete Postlethwaite), her perspective is changed forever. But surrounded by enemies and with a mission still to complete, what can Aeon do about it? After an Oscar win for Monster and a probable second nomination on the way for North Country, nobody can possibly doubt that Charlize Theron can act. In Aeon Flux, however, we see less of Theron's stellar abilities than we do her incredible good looks. In fact, Theron appears in one skin tight costume after the next (and wait until you see what she sleeps in, boys!) which are so overtly intended to be sexy that they actually begin to take away from what Aeon really is and what Theron is otherwise capable of doing. Sophie Okonedo's Sithandra actually fares a bit better here as she's allowed to be exactly what she and Aeon are supposed to be, that being highly trained agents of revolution.

Martin Czokas comes off well, appearing earnest and natural before the cameras. Jonny Lee Miller, though, smirks his way through the film with a "look at me, I'm in the movies!" attitude, while the brilliant Frances McDormond (who gave a terrific performance opposite Theron in North Country) is woefully miscast.

The storyline is relatively thin, though I'm not sure we should have expected more than from a film based on some MTV animated characters. The inexperienced director (Karyn Kasuma, who has only one small film under her belt) was in over her head as evidenced by two-dimensional performances from even the best actors as well as choppy edits.

The film's writers may have aimed for "surreal," but would have been better served had they set their sights more toward just plain "real" since much of the dialogue tried much too hard to seem like the people talking might be living in the distant future. Overt inconsistencies also mar the screenplay. Meanwhile, the film's costumers fell into an identical trap, making collars stick up and cutting fabric asymmetrically with a "look, we're in the future!" wink as they did so.

The cinematography, though, was quite good; so was the set design. The stunt work was impressive to say the least (Theron performed most of her own stunts, and looked just fine doing so). And, not surprisingly, special effects are everywhere. Fortunately, they're very, very well done.

As a whole, Aeon Flux is all right if you're feeling "science fictiony." As eye candy alone, it's frankly worth the price of admission. But missed opportunities to be so much deeper and, as a result, better, make Aeon Flux as a whole a disappointment at best.

POLITICAL NOTES: At one point, Aeon Flux notes that the residents of Bregna "gave up freedom for life in a gilded cage." While Bregna is lovely and no one is homeless or hungry, it's just as true that everybody is watched on a constant basis, and that armed patrols on the streets make it clear that the beauty is only skin deep. That's a valid point, and one I appreciate the movie having made. Far worse for our own present day reality, however, was the reaction of one amateur reviewer who took issue with anybody railing against a government that took such good care of its citizens. It's that attitude that will make the gilded cage scenario all the more likely in our own future, and we can bet that it won't be nearly so pretty as the on screen Bregna when it happens.

FAMILY SUITABILITY: Aeon Flux is rated PG-13 for "sequences of violence and sexual content." That rating seems about right to me. Small children will be scared by some of the action sequences; they also won't understand even the most basic portions of the plot (such as it is). Teen (and even older) boys will love the film based solely on Theron's costumes, and I can see their point; science fiction fans will also have a little something to whet their appetites until the next big (and hopefully better) Hollywood offering comes along. In the main, however, if you've got Christmas shopping to do, you might want to skip the movies this weekend and hold out for the upcoming Chronicles of Narnia instead.

I would like to start off by saying that I am a huge fan of the MTV cartoon show of the early/mid-1990s, and that I always will be. It is simply not very interesting without the Aeon Flux we all know and love, by which I mean the character, not the identically-named character played by Theron. review_title: Outstanding visuals. And, for a change, I mean that.
review_detailed_main:
The visual artists of this film should have received the Academy Award. Production Designer Andrew McAlpine; Artistic directors Marco Bittner Rosser, Sarah Horton, and Andreas Olshausen; Set Designer Berhard Henrich; Costume Designer Beatrix Aruna Pasztor; the makeup artists; even the hair designers. It's all good.

You've got to understand, I have never been a fan of the visuals-driven movie. Occasionally a film is so revolutionary (Blade Runner, Edward Scissorhands, The Matrix) that you simply have to applaud, but most of those movies have other things going for them. Far, FAR too much crapola gets filmed these days and passed off as 'art' when all it really is is 'flashy.' The worst offenders have always been genre flicks (fantasy, horror, sci-fi), and the worst of *those* have been supposedly "futuristic" science fiction films which take their 'vision o' the future' oh-so-seriously, yet fail to understand that the future's changes will be more than simply grim recreations of 1930's Germany (Equilibrium) or a rather glitzy version of an L.A. mall scene (Ultraviolet).

Finally, with Aeon Flux, there seems to have been some real care taken. The clothing, the architecture, even the foodstuffs have a slightly-slimy, neoprene 'wetness' to them which goes right along with the core themes of bio-engineering, yet manages to avoid ripping off either H.R. Giger or the Watchowski Brothers. Kudos to them for producing what is, yes, an effects-driven film, but one in which those effects serve the mood and purpose of the narrative.

Oh, the plot and characters and whatnot? Yeah, forgettable schlock. But who cares, these days, other than some self-important, smug, high-brow critical types anyway?

review_title: It could have been better, but it certainly could also have been worse
review_detailed_main: I did watch some of the animated series that precedes this, but I can't be claimed to have really followed it, so I honestly don't have a basis of comparison. From what I understand, it's better and/or much more complicated than the movie. Throughout watching, I didn't really dislike this, not as such... it certainly has its moments, and tends to entertain. The plot isn't horrible, and has an idea or two of interest... it does come off a bit like an agenda-driven piece, at times(to say what exactly I'm referring to would be revealing spoilers), and whether or not you agree with the message(if it is well-delivered, on the whole), well, there are other forums for expressing such, and it wasn't really evident that it was going to be such... and if you spend about an hour and a half watching something, you ought to take more away from it than something that could be summed up in the words "*insert word* is bad"(but I would say that I did). The writing is hit-and-miss. Dialog does have some lines that are reasonable, but the poor ones are, at times, awful. The story does perhaps feature an instance or two of the scene that they *really* wanted in there being put in even though it contradicts something else in the film. Æon is almost/maybe *too* strong and skilled, and is too seldom in true danger... a flaw that this shares with Ultraviolet, but that picture has the advantage of some utterly unique, stylized imagery(and some *unbelievable* action), and where this does have, well, somewhat stylish visuals, there could still have been more tension in the action scenes(on the other hand, much of it is pretty cool... though there are occasions where the camera doesn't realize where it should point until it's too late). The editing and cinematography are fairly standard, which isn't necessarily a bad thing... except for when there are such odd angles and cuts that it takes you out of the experience, which is. The technical aspects seem rather marred by there being cut too many corners(why all the reused footage?), to the point where it more or less gets difficult to ignore or overlook. The special effects vary, but some are good. The look is nicely done, costumes, props, all the way(possibly more the design than the actual execution). Pacing is decent, I was never really bored. All in all, it is definitely watchable. Worth watching? Well, if you know what to expect, and the film is what you want... I enjoyed it, not everyone will. Don't go in thinking you'll be treated to mind-blowing sci-fi, action of Matrix proportions or execution, or something that will make you re-think your life... instead, just know that the action is awesome more often than it isn't, and that not-rid-of-clichés plot is not as stupid as that of an awful lot of sci-fi action fare. I recommend this to those interested in what I describe immediately preceding this sentence. Fans of the show may find themselves disappointed. 6/10

While the original anime had a strong kinky sexual vibe, lots of social commentary undertones, and lots of gratuitous violence. Yeah, Theron isn't in the scantily clad combat outfit, but if you can forget about slavish adherence to detail, she still looks damn good in Lycra. She does look too chubby to be Aeon (a long faced, sinewy anorexic), but has the vocal tone and facial expressions. Marlon does not vaguely resemble Goodchild, but the story is different, so his acting matches the movie rendition.

I find it incredible irony that a movie production decides to inject "plot" into a cartoon, improves it from a content point of view, and yet fails horribly at the box office. But its not a HORRIBLE movie. I'd kinda put it in The Island or Sky Captain level sci-fi movie.

review_title: More Than Just an MTV Action Film
review_detailed_main:
When Charlize Theron starred as sympathetic serial killer Aileen Wuornos in Monster, I decided to myself that this actor can do ANYTHING! When she got cast as Aeon Flux in the live action adaptation of the MTV animated series of the same name, I was more than ecstatic. I had no doubt that this actor could do this character justice and play her believably and realistically.

Upon viewing the film, I was right. Theron's Aeon sounds and acts just like the animated version; the movie looks and feels just like the animated series, right down to the weird camera angles and all; and the storyline is multi layered and up for personal interpretation as well. Just like the animated series.

All involved obviously had a huge love for the series, but also made sure the movie stood on it's own. The movie could easily be seen as an episode of the series, as well as a stand alone feature.

As usual, Aeon is trying to kill Trevor and as usual, she can't because she loves him. The movie includes one other character from the series - Sithandra, who has two hands where her two feet should be - and introduces Aeon's sister - Una Flux - who becomes a central plot point in the movie.

What sets the movie apart from other action movies is that the action is secondary. The plot is central and really does drive the actions of the characters. While there is plenty of action scenes, they are usually set against really beautiful backdrops: a cherry tree garden, a secret minimalist room, the city of Bregna itself.

Creator Peter Chung was a little more displeased with this product, but that's expected, especially considering he had little to no involvement with this piece. Director Karyn Kusama, who also directed Girlfight, really strives for the look and feel of Peter Chung's creation. While there is talk of extra scenes that were exercised out of the film, the finished product feels like a classic all on it's own. A real treat for fans of the series, fans of action films and those looking to watch a movie that makes them think.

But a note to creater Peter Chung. How about making your own Aeon Flux film? Animated and all? http://neonboy619.blogspot.com
